item.title: 10 Great Articles about Go
item.author: Andy Rees
item.description:
The fastest way to mastery in any field is to emulate expertise of those at the top of their field. With that in mind, I have collected a few great links and articles that will catapult you into their esteemed company in no time at all.

  1. Building Web Apps with Go

    Learn how to build and deploy web applications with Go. A useful overview from the creator of Martini and Negroni.

    Read

  2. Go Concurrency Patterns

    Go’s concurrency primitives make it easy to construct streaming data pipelines that make efficient use of I/O and multiple CPUs. This article presents examples of such pipelines, highlights subtleties that arise when operations fail, and introduces techniques for dealing with failures cleanly.

    article

  3. Go Training Classes by Ardan Studios

    The Ardan Labs Go Bootcamp is a 3 day class providing a comprehensive and idiomatic view of the Go programming language. The class covers topics ranging from language syntax, OOP, concurrency, channels, testing, debugging and more. Great for anyone interested in getting a jump start on learning Go or wanting to understand more about the language and internals. But if you can’t make it to the course, the code and course notes are available here.

    notes

  4. Twelve Go Best Practices, Francesc Campoy Flores


    slides

  5. Whispering Gophers, Network programming in Go, by Andrew Gerrand & Francesc Campoy. A great code lab that demonstrates network programming in Go.

    slides

  6. 10 things you (probably) don’t know about Go, Andrew Gerrand

    slides

  7. Go: code that grows with grace, Andrew Gerrand

    Go: code that grows with grace from Øredev Conference on Vimeo.

    slides

  8. A Tour of the Go Programming Language, Russ Cox


  9. Go for Gophers, Andrew Gerrand


    slides

  10. JSON, interfaces, and go generate, Francesc Campoy

item.title: 5 Ways to become the MacGyver of Go
item.author: Andy Rees
item.description:
5 Ways to become the MacGyver of Go, with nothing more than a paperclip, an elastic band, a magnet and the Go Standard Library

Install the Go toolset from source.

This might sound crazy, as there are package installers available for most operating systems. But it has one really useful side effect. You can then create a cross compilation toolchain. So you can easily release multiple versions of your Go app. for instructions, click here.

One great tool for this is “mitchellh/gox”.

$ go get github.com/mitchellh/gox
...
$ gox -h
...

Before you use Gox, you must build the cross-compilation toolchain. Gox can do this for you. This only has to be done once (or whenever you update Go):

$ gox -build-toolchain
...

Once that is done, you’re ready to cross compile!

Pimp your favourite editor

I don’t care how long you have been programming, nobody can remember the entire standard libray for a language.

This tends to create bad habits, as you can end up putting great effort into writing a piece of code and then find out later that it already exists in the standard library.

THios is where code completion, syntax highlighters come in to there own, as they can speed up the familiarity with the SL.

For Go, there are a number of great ones, but in my opinion, GoSublime for SublimeText2 / 3 is above them all, as it works with the installed version, so update your go toolchain and the code completion gos with it. It will also complete for your own packages.

  • SublimeText, link
  • GoSublime, link

Learn the Standard Library

Save yourself the pain of reinventing the wheel and become familiar with the standard Library. Some good resources for this are the following books:

  • Go, The Standard Library, Daniel Huckstep
  • The Way to Go: A Thorough Introduction to the Go Programming Language, by Ivo Balbaert

Make use of http://godoc.org

GoDoc is a Go package search engine that hosts documentation for Go packages on Bitbucket, GitHub, Launchpad and Google Project Hosting.

It should be the first stop when creating a project that requires a new, complex package to be written, as it is quite likely that the functionlity already exists.

Start doing the Reddit Daily Programmer Challenge

The only way to effectively learn a language is to speak it regularly, but if your daily routine doesn’t provide this for you, there is always the Reddit Daily Programmer Challenge.

Find our more information here

The challenges are always language agnostic and are posted three times a week at differing levels of difficulty. So no matter your level, you will find an interesting way to develop you programming skills.

See the challenges here

item.title: How to start using Go
item.author: Andy Rees
item.description:
Go is a fast strongly typed, garbage collected modern language developed by Google and the open-source community. It can be deployed as a single binary and can easily cross compile for other platforms.

Here are a few handy links an tutorials to get you started

  1. The Official Google, web based tour of the Go Programming Language. To get started with it, you don’t even need to have the tools installed. The following link provides an interactive web-based tutorial, and even has labs.

    Tour of Go

  2. Installation of the Go toolset. When you are ready to give it a go on your own system, this guide wil help you get set up.

    Go Installation

  3. Getting started with Go

  4. Effective Go way. How to write idiomatic code the Go way.

    Effective Go

  5. Go By Example. This site has some great code examples of the basics of the language.

    Go By Example
